title: Writing Workshop: Cultural Criticism, Media Writing, and Transmedia Storytelling
description: This course explores the art of writing across various formats and media. Designed to enhance students’ critical and creative capabilities, the course is divided into three parts: cultural criticism, media writing, and transmedia storytelling.The first section focuses on the function, language, and format of cultural criticism. The course introduces the core principles of writing critique on literature, films, popular culture, and visual art. Students are invited to discuss the works both aesthetically and critically. Another section of the course focuses on the fundamental skills specific to the media forms of print, digital platforms, and social media. Foregrounded with a comprehensive understanding of media infrastructures, students will be able to develop skills in collecting information, generating ideas, organizing the structure of their writing, and effectively presenting their thoughts.The final section draws on Henry Jenkins’s concept of “convergence.” We will compare the conventions of traditional narratives with the world of transmedia storytelling, including but not limited to the ‘converging’ realms of YouTube, podcasts, and interactive content on social media. Students will learn to develop storytelling skills while making good use of media platforms for content distribution.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: State and recognise the definition of criticism, media writing and transmedia storytelling. List and clarify principles and skills to structure their criticism, media writing and transmedia storytelling. Apply various strategies to enchant their language and improve their accuracy, clarity and conciseness in writing criticism. Create and design media content and transmedia storytelling with critical thinking.

title: Video Production
description: This is an advanced course that focuses on practical application in the field of visual imagery. Students are required to have previously taken CURE2066 or possess a solid understanding of visual design principles, as well as basic proficiency in Adobe Photoshop and Adobe Premiere, along with some experience in beginner-level photography.The course is comprised of lectures, readings, workshops, and practical image projects. Compared to CURE2066, this course delves further into advanced techniques of using Adobe Premiere and combines them with foundational skills in Adobe After Effects to explore the process of creating various visual effects. Building upon the instructional foundation of conventional elements in video production, such as photography, recording, and lighting, this course also covers and practices multiple shooting methods, including mobile photography, sports photography, and drone photography. These various shooting approaches enable students to effectively convey their creative ideas through rich visual forms, helping them explore and develop their own visual expression style while preparing them for future employment opportunities.

title: Islamic Scriptures: The Qur’an and Traditions of Muhammad
description: This course introduces and examines the main sacred textual sources of Islam: The Qur'an and the Hadith (Prophetic Traditions). Topics include the texts’ structure, content and style, their relationship to one another, their function in Muslim religious and communal life, and their place in Islamic historical, theological, legal and mystical contexts.

title: Religious Education and Developmental Psychology
description: This course will examine the contemporary theories and researches in the field of developmental psychology, and consider their relevance to the field of Religious Education. Issues of moral development, faith development and spiritual development will specifically be considered. Attention will also be given to the implications of developmental perspectives for prospective religious educators in understanding themselves, the persons with whom they work, and the structures that best promote whole person development.
outcome: Upon completing the course, students should be able to: a.comprehend the human developmental processes throughout the life span; b.understand the theories related to moral, faith and spiritual development; c.increase awareness of the relationship of religion, to education and general well being; d.develop creative strategies for facilitating optimal development over the life-span by using religious resources; e.self-examine the student's stage of personal and spiritual development, reflecting on the implications for her/his role as a religious educator; f.critically evaluate and discuss different psychological (i.e. evolutionary, cognitive, social, phenomenological) approaches to religion. g.apply concepts in developmental psychology to specific educational contexts.
syllabus: Week 1: Course Introduction: The Place of Religious Education in Whole Person Development Week 2: Religious Development in Children Week 3: Religious Development Through the Lifespan: Adolescence and Adulthood Week 4: Moral Development Across the Life Span    Week 5: Faith Development Across the Life Span Week 6: Religion and Personality Development Week 7: Religion, Value Formation in the Life Cycle Week 8: Varieties of Religious Experience and the Development of Spiritual Mind Week 9: Loss: Lifespan Approach Week 10: Death and Dying Week 11: Gender Issues in Whole Person Development Week 12: Religious Education, Whole Person Development and Well Being Week 13: Quiz and Course Conclusion

title: Religion and Globalization
description: In this course we will explore the changing role of religions in the context of globalization. The course examines how religions in global societies reflect and help shape globalization processes related to the economy, politics, culture, media, and other areas. At the end of the term, the students will work with the course instructor on building case studies of how religious groups intend to change world societies.

title: Chinese Buddhism
description: This course is a study of the propagation of Buddhist religion in China, the formation of schools and the problems of Buddhist confrontation and harmonization with indigenous Chinese culture.

title: Popular Religions in China
description: This course is a study of the popular religious consciousness of the Chinese, the roots of religion in ancient China, the ancestral cult, the concepts of gods and immortals, the formation of religious sects, religious expressions of the community, festivals, myths, geomancy, divination, etc.

title: Religious Imagination and Visual Art
description: This course introduces students to the study of religion, art and visual culture. Through visible expression and form in religious art across human history, we will explore the questions including: (1) how human beings see the world religiously? what does it mean to see the world religiously? (2) how do visual arts tell us about the ways that religions practiced but are not included in written scripture? and (4) how might the role of visual objects affect the way we study religion?

title: Religious Texts in Translation
description: This course provides an introduction to the theories and practice of translating religious texts. It allows students to become aware of the issues, difficulties and strategies involved in cross-cultural transfer and translation. The phenomenon of cultural accommodation and/or transgression as well as inter-religious dialogue in the process of translation will be critically examined. Selected texts may include Chinese translations of the Bible, the Koran, the Buddhist scriptures, missionary tracts and religious allegories like The Pilgrim's Progress. The English translations of Chinese religious novels like Wu Cheng'en's The Journey to the West and Cao Xueqin's The Story of the Stone will also be analyzed.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 1. Demonstrate a knowledge of the basic principles and practice of translation;  2. Understand the difficulties and contributions of cross-cultural rewriting of religious texts;  3. Reflect critically on the phenomenon of cultural transfer and inter-religious dialogue in the process of translation.

title: Chinese Literature and the Bible
description: The Union Version of the Bible (1919) constitutes an important factor in shaping modern Chinese literature and the vernacular movement in the early twentieth century. A large number of works of May Fourth writers (such as Lu Xun, Bing Xin and Xu Dishan) are filled with biblical images, themes, allusions and quotations. Meanwhile, many Chinese translations of the Bible are heavily influenced by the Chinese cultural and literary traditions. For instance, Yan Fu’s translation of the Gospel of Mark employs an elegant style of classical Chinese, while Wu Jingxiong’s Psalms adopts the refined forms of Shijing (The Book of Songs) and Chuci (The Songs of Chu). This course aims to examine the intricate interactions between Chinese literature and the Bible, particularly the influences of Chinese literary traditions on the translations of the Bible and the rhetorical influences of the Bible on the emergence of modern Chinese literature, with a view to widening students’ perspectives in the interdisciplinary study of literature and religion.

title: Chinese Novels and Religion
description: Chinese novels have long been intertwined with religion. While Confucian, Buddhist and Daoist thoughts permeate classical Chinese novels, a large number of modern Chinese novels are peppered with Christian elements. As a lively epitome of Chinese religious culture, these novels also promoted the spread of religious thoughts among the people. This course aims to investigate the interactive relationship between Chinese novels and religion. Students will be guided to examine the religious contents in novels and the ways in which religious thoughts shape the themes, narratives, characterization and language of the novels. Texts selected for reading include classical and modern novels, such as Strange Tales of Liaozhai, The Story of the Stone and The Journey to the West.
outcome: 1.學生能認識宗教、文學與文化之間的互動關係； 2.學生能欣賞中國小說的敘事特徵及表現手法； 3.學生能分析中國小說中的宗教內涵和象徵意義。

title: The Religious Policy and Practices in China Today
description: This course studies the religious policy in China, focusing on: 1) the Constitution, legislation and official statements as they relate to the question of religion; and 2) implementation and accommodation for various religious practices during different political periods.
outcome: 1. 掌握新中國成立迄今黨國宗教政策的演變 2. 從政教關係的脈絡下認識不同宗教的發展空間 3. 認識中國宗教自由的現況及限制
syllabus: 一．導論：政教關係、宗教政策與宗教自由 二．政教關係與宗教政策的回顧：從帝制時期到建國前的中國共產黨 三．毛澤東時代：全能政治的發展 四．反帝愛國：全能政治與宗教革新運動 五．鄧小平時代與鄧後時期：威權體制與改革開放 六．從人民鴉片到「相適應」：新時期宗教理論的發展 七．新時期宗教工作及政策的發展 八．「上有政策，下有對策」：宗教政策的落實問題 九．「五大宗教」的發展與制約 十．民間信仰、新興宗教與邪教問題 十一．中國宗教政策的前膽與展望
required_readings: 1.Kindopp, Jason & Carol Lee, Hamrin,. God and Caesar in China: Policy Implications of Church-State Tensions. Washington, D. C.: Brookings Institution Press, 2004. 2.邢福增：《當代中國政教關係》（香港：建道神學院，1999）。 3.邢福增：《新酒與舊皮袋──中國宗教立法與〈宗教事務條例解讀〉》（香港：中文大學崇基學院宗教與中國社會研究中心，2006）。

title: Spirituality, Psychology and Well-Being
description: This course explores the intersection of spirituality, psychology, and well-being, providing students with a comprehensive understanding of how these areas are interconnected. Students will examine various psychological perspectives on spirituality, explore the impact of spirituality on mental health and well-being, and learn practical strategies for integrating spirituality into their personal and professional lives. The course will also cover contemporary research and theories in the field, allowing students to critically analyze and evaluate the role of spirituality in fostering psychological well-being.

title: Buddhism and Contemporary Life
requirements: Not for students who have taken UGED3322 or UGED2331
description: (UGED3322 is double-coded with CURE3145.)   This course studies Buddhism and contemporary life in the context of the new development of Buddhism. It examines how Buddhism is reinvented and reconceptualized to make it meaningful for men and women living in modern complex society of the information age. Based on the recent development of Buddhism in both Asia and in the West, this course discusses how Buddhism responds to contemporary issues facing contemporary men and women. Topics include the Buddhist approach to economic development and human right, pollution and biotechnology, feminism, Buddhist ethics and the issues of abortion, euthanasia and suicide, Buddhism and interfaith dialogue.

title: Religion and Mental Health Care
description: This course adopts an interdisciplinary approach to teach the history and contemporary evolution of "Religion and Mental Health Care". The course will focus on teaching the traditional concepts, practices and self-cultivation related to mental health in Christianity, Buddhism, and Daoism from ancient to contemporary times based on historical and textual materials. It will also teach counselling and psychotherapy related to religious traditions, and provide in-depth discussions on specific mental health care topics. Students in this course will be able to integrate traditional and modern religious knowledge and mental health care applications, giving them a deep understanding of the mutual impact of religion and mental health. That includes understanding evidence-based research on religious behaviors and mental health, and also reviewing interventions related to religious traditions, such as mindfulness, dharma therapy, nourishing life, and qigong. The course also explores life and death education, bereavement, resilience, chaplaincy's practices, and mental health caregivers’ self-care.

title: Science and Religion
description: (UGED3430 is double-coded with CURE3375.)  This course mainly investigates the relationship between religion and natural sciences. The course will cover the following aspects: 1) historical investigation of the relationship between religion and natural sciences; 2) comparison between methodology of natural sciences and religious studies; and 3) religious dealings with different issues arising from scientific discoveries and technological advancements; ecology and religion; and the nature of science and religion in the postmodern culture.
outcome: Having fully engaged with the course, students are expected to have: (1)   a basic knowledge of the ways of relating science and religion;(2)   a basic familiarity with the encounter between science and religion in history;(3)   a basic understanding of the similarities and differences between scientific method and religious method;(4)   an ability to engage in interdisciplinary dialogues between science and religion concerning various important human issues;(5)   a basic appreciation of the compatibility between science and religion;(6)   an awareness of the importance of the religious studies as an intellectual discipline to correlate human science and physical science.

title: Fieldwork in Indian Religions and Culture
description: This course aims to introduce students to the major religions, traditions and cultures of India, with the exception of Islam. It offers students a lively and effective learning experience through fieldwork. There are two options for fieldwork which students can choose from. 1: Visiting various Hindu, Sikh and Jain temples in Hong Kong2: A 10 day visit to India that will include visiting both religious and historical sites.In both cases students will learn through first-hand exposure to religious relics, sites, material culture and personal interactions with Indian practitioners of different faiths. The sites of visit will be organized and led by experienced member(s) of the teaching staff. Sites to be visited in Hong Kong and India will include mainstream traditions within the broad framework of Hinduism, such as the Vaishnava Bhakti movement and the Shaiva tradition. Field work will also include visits to traditions that originally arose as challenges to mainstream Hinduism such as the Jains, Buddhists and Sikhs. There will be six lectures conducted on campus prior to the fieldwork that will offer students an overview of the geographical, philosophical and historical background of the sites that will be visited and the traditions we will interact with. Students who select option 1 will spend the rest of the term on fieldwork in Hong Kong. This will be planned together with the instructor. For students who select option 2 a ten day trip to India during the Christmas holidays will be arranged. Fieldwork should add up to approximately 21 hours of off campus learning which will include on-site lectures, on-the-spot investigations and tutorial discussions during the trip. Both a pre-trip and a post-trip assignment in the form of a reading report, essay and/or presentation are required. . It should be noted that enrolment for option 2 is limited to 25 persons with the course being conducted in English and Chinese. For more details regarding option 2 please contact the department. Course content:I. Lectures(1) History and geography of India(2) Jainism and Zoroastrainism(3) Sikhism(4) Bahai’i(5) The Vaishnava Bhakti movement(6) Planning for FieldworkII. Fieldwork

title: Fieldwork in Islamic Culture and Religion
requirements: Co-requisite(s): CURE1126 or CURE2151 or CURE1123/UGED1400
description: This course aims to introduce students to the history, Islamic culture and religion of various Muslim societies. It offers students a lively and effective learning experience on Islam through fieldwork in both Hong Kong and in a Muslim society abroad (destination to be announced at the beginning of the course). We will be (1) visiting mosques and Islamic centers in Hong Kong on one Saturday and (2) going on a 7-10 day visit to an overseas Muslim society in May that will include visiting both religious and historical sites. Students will learn through first-hand exposure to religious relics, sites, material culture and personal interactions with practitioners of Islam. The visit of sites will be organized and led by the teaching staff. Students are required to attend at least six lectures and finish a book report and/or an essay and a presentation before and during our visit to a Muslim society overseas.

title: Hong Kong Culture and Heritage
description: This course introduces students to critical approaches and practices related to cultural heritage, with a focus on case studies from Hong Kong. It emphasizes the interdisciplinary nature of the field and encourages students to challenge and reflect on “Eurocentric” theories and practices of heritage. Structured thematically, the first part of the course covers current debates in both the theory and practice of cultural heritage, including issues such as definition, authenticity, ethics, tangible and intangible heritage, cultural rights, commodification, sustainability, and inclusiveness. The second part of the course uses case studies from Hong Kong to examine how certain sites or practices have been institutionalized and listed as local or international heritages. It also explores various models of defining and managing Hong Kong's cultural heritage. By the end of the course, students will be able to think beyond “Eurocentric” heritage concepts and practices, and be aware of the correlation between Hong Kong cultural heritage, identity, and community.

title: Film and Independent Cinema
description: From the emergence of Hollywood's studio and star systems to the diversity of international cinema, including the rise of independent and avant-garde movements, and the expansion of cinema on online platforms, the study of cinema encompasses various facets, such as industry, artistic expression, and cultural and curatorial practices. This course situates cinema within extensive aesthetic, economic, and curatorial frameworks, offering students foundational knowledge in film analysis, film studies languages and concepts, the history of both mainstream and independent films, and the evolving technological, cultural, and generic significance of film. These often intersect with issues of cultural identity, representation, and power structures.Additionally, the course addresses the curatorial aspects of film exhibitions and festivals in various venues, such as festivals, museums, archives, online platforms, and emerging virtual technologies. Students interested in cultural management and cultural studies in the context of film and independent cinema will gain the skills to analyze, curate, and critically engage with film, focusing on models, aesthetics, culture, and curatorial practices.

title: Media Arts Management
description: This course introduces a new genre in the art discipline that employs electronic and digital devices as the main medium of communication. The course contains three sessions. The first session explains the birth of this set of contemporary art practices in relation to the Dadaist movement of the early twentieth century that opened up new concepts for visual arts. This will be followed by a session that discusses the range of media now commonly adopted in the discipline, including video, photography, computer graphics, webpage, and the Internet. Different set of techniques are involved in these productions, and they often generate quite different social impacts that affect both the producers and the users. Students are instructed to understand both the technological and social aspects of these areas. The last session comprises a series of workshops that lead students to appreciate and comment on the most featured productions. Emphasis is placed on the angle to promote this new art type as a rising cultural sector in the society.

title: Public and Community Art
description: Public art is considered as an important cultural asset of metropolitan cities, closely related to city images and development. Community art serves as a tool for community development, based on the understanding that expression, mastery and communication through the arts powerfully encode cultural values, thus bringing deeper meanings of experience, participation and involvement, sense of belonging to the general public and the community. This course aims to advance students’ understanding of public and community arts by embedding them in the theoretical discussions and critiques of cities and public spaces and practical experiences. It also imparts the knowledge and skills about managing public arts and actualizing community art programs, and discusses the way to support their development responding to the needs.
outcome: In terms of knowledge acquisition, students are expected to understand how public and community arts emerged in the context of urban regeneration and community activist movements. Students are encouraged to critically analyze the meanings and social values of public art spaces. In terms of managerial concepts and skills, students will learn how public and community arts are supported by government policies, material resources, infrastructure and training. Students are expected to understand public art commission and reception, to master basic principles of utilizing public art as an urban design strategy, and to apply varying approaches to facilitating community art development, for example, advancing community art education, utilizing the cultural planning approach to assess community based cultural resources and the place-event approach to creating a sense of community attachment.
syllabus: Part I. Understanding Public and Community Art 1. General Introduction This section begins with displaying a range of public and community art cases and presents an introduction to the course. Three issues are covered in this introductory lecture. First, this section provides the conceptual discussions of public space, public art, and their art forms to enable students to understand what public art space and public art is. Second, this section explores the role of artists in public art space and community development. Third, a historical picture of public art is unfolded, which traces its origin, displays its developing process, and takes a glimpse into its enshrined social values.   2. Understanding Public Art Spaces  How should we understand public art spaces and the public nature of public art? This section embeds these issues into the understanding of a city; it then conveys the ideas that public spaces are socially produced and that city forms are imbued with ideologies. Public art stems from an urban setting and then grows through the urban regeneration movement, which comprises several issues, such as urban image, urban form and urban planning as well as their connections with public art space as a form of representational space. Furthermore, this section explores the public nature of public art by examining the process, by which artists derive value from individual creativity in the studios and immense it into the public space.  Tutorial: Discuss the alternative history of public art (Lacy, 1995, 25–28).  3. Public Art: The Monument The monument is an important theoretical perspective to conceptualize public art. This section explains what a “monument” is and investigates its role—whether statue, memorial, or public statue—in upholding a value-laden system of Western society. Issues under examination range from the connection between monument and national identity, the power and representation of public arts, the transformative understanding of public art as a monument, and the contradictions of public art.  Tutorial: Discuss the public nature of public art.  4. Critical Issues of Public Art Spaces Who comprise the “audience” of public arts? What does “intention” mean and what is the “effectiveness” of public art? This section further discusses the theories on critical issues related to public art. This section begins with the discussions of the relevant terms and proceeds to various critical thoughts that challenge the value of public art and question its public nature. Students are expected to be able to analyze public art spaces and public art critically. Tutorial: Develop critical thinking about public art spaces and public art.  5. Public Arts and Community Cultural Development: Theoretical Underpinnings of Community Art This section provides a synopsis of the histories and theoretical issues of community art. The origin of community art is traced to the discourse of William Morris’s call for social reintegration of artists and a revival of art in the 19th century. Theoretical issues include the “popular front” and class consciousness, civil rights and identity politics, as well as cultural democracy and exchange. In addition, this section discusses the definitions of community, the role of community art, and the core purposes of community development.  Tutorial: Discuss the question, “What makes art valuable?”   Part II. Public Art Management  6. Commission and Reception of Public Art Based on the public nature of art, this section analyzes the process of art making, which comprises the elements of audience, context, and meaning. The process includes the following: acquiring cultural approval, arriving in public sites and places, providing visiting experiences with the audience, and generating meanings. Cases of Seattle and New York are used for this study. With regard to art reception, it analyzes the issues of taste, the education of the audience, as well as the relationship of art to society and popular visual culture. In addition, this section also distinguishes performance culture from monumental public art. Tutorial: Distinguish public art from community art.  7. Public Art and Urban Design This section presents an urban design approach to commissioning and making public art. It outlines the principles for creating a city image, which consists of five elements, and discusses their connections to public art. Various forms of public art in association with the urban setting and the mechanism of public art utilization as an urban design strategy are also discussed. Students are guided toward understanding the role of public arts in urban design guidelines. Moreover, we also discussed a set of design principles on the relationship between public art and various urban forms and spatial components, aimed at integrating public art into the urban setting as context and reference is discussed. Tutorial: Conduct design software training.  Assignment: Find a sample of public art (i.e., sculpture) using design principles to assess its location, site, and designs as well as to evaluate its strengths and weaknesses. Write a paper based on the research and use the design software to illustrate the arguments.   8. Government Policies for Public and Community Art Development The relation between power and public and community art is a critical issue in public and community art management. This section discusses the governmental structure that funds and commissions public art, the infrastructure that underpins public art, and the governmental policies that support community art. The selection of commissions and projects is discussed, along with the process of seeking public and professional responses. International and the local Hong Kong contexts are examined to explore how government policies affect public and community art. In the local context, the role of the Leisure and Cultural Services Department in promoting public art in Hong Kong is adopted as a case study. Tutorial: Conduct an in-class test.   9. Public Art in Metropolitan Cities This section analyzes the role of public art in metropolitan cities, especially in the spheres of public transport, public open spaces, and public health system. A number of cases are presented, including forms of public art in the New York Subway system, London Underground and Mass Transit Railway, and the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Hong Kong. The issue of commissioning public arts is revisited in the public art in metropolitan context.  Tutorial: Discuss urban design and public art in Hong Kong.  Part III. Community Art Management 10. Developmental Needs of the Field How can community art development be supported? What do communities need? This section specifies the scope of cultural policies and the policy climate that community artists and community cultural development require. Moreover, this section discusses the material support that community cultural organizations and artists need, including funding supports and internal infrastructure and exchange. Tutorial: Discuss the cultural policies for public art in Hong Kong.  11. From Theory to Practice I: Process to Develop Community Arts From theory to practice, this section offers students a general orientation, which serves as a road map to the community-based art process. Five conceptual territories to advance community-based art as well as requisite techniques to fulfill tasks are introduced in this section, which include the following: 1) contacting people in the community; 2) conducting research on the culture of the community and the people’s perception of their community; 3) taking actions to make art projects; 4) gaining feedbacks from the community; and 5) incorporating these art forms into community art education programs to pass on skills and sustain the impact. The program also includes strategies for planning and organizing community outreach and engagement programs as well as ways to enhance public awareness. Tutorial: Discuss the process of applying theories in the creation of community art in order to practice and initiate the group project with the community.  12. From Theory to Practice II: Key Issues in Community Art Development Based on the holistic picture of the steps to develop community arts, this section focuses on certain key and challenging issues in the process, specifically those on research methods and art making. The section introduces qualitative and quantitative research methods for the project of community art development, and students are expected to learn how to identify survey areas, design survey questionnaires, run group discussions, and map cultural mind-sets and assets. Another key issue is how to make arts and work with artists. An artist will be invited to be the guest speaker to give the lesson. Tutorial: Develop a group project with the community.   13. Review and discussions Students will present their on-going group projects on community art development, and the professor then provides comments and feedbacks on their projects. Key points of this course will also be reviewed in this class.

title: Design Your Exhibition – Curatorial Planning and Practice
requirements:
Pre-requisite: CUMT2007
Not for students who have taken CUMT3005.
description: “Curator” once referred to an expert in keeping collections and making exhibitions, but has been expanded to encompass a hybrid role in innovation and knowledge creation. Today, curators are active agents in social and cultural transformation, taking part in dynamic projects presented by museums, commercial galleries, non-profit art spaces, biennials, art fairs, and many disruptive platforms beyond the field of art that didn’t previously exist. Curators produce knowledge, engage their audience, spark innovation, and constantly challenge the role of “curator” beyond the confines of the status quo across varied institutional settings. This course aims to provide students with hands-on experience in exhibition curation and engages students in a broad spectrum of real-world experiences and professional networking opportunities, aiming to prepare students for future curatorial projects/jobs. It covers topics such as idea conceptualization, proposal writing, pitching, budgeting, contracting, publication, exhibition design, installation and exhibition maintenance. By co-curating an exhibition in a non-profit art space in Hong Kong, students will take part in the various stages of exhibition making. With a focus on exhibition experience, audience engagement, and sociability, this course will train students in the role of being a curator and enable students to develop leadership skills and critically apply knowledge conducive to creative outcomes.

title: Popular Music and Industry
description: “Popular Music and Industry” is an interdisciplinary course that examines the complex relationship between popular music, culture, arts management, and the evolving music industry. Students will explore the historical development of popular music genres and styles, analyze the interplay between music and society, and evaluate the key stakeholders, business models, and technological transformations that have shaped the popular music landscape over time. Through a combination of international case studies, critical discussions, and hands-on research, students will develop a comprehensive understanding of the popular music industry, from record labels and publishing to streaming platforms and live events. The course will also explore and assess the impact of globalization, cultural exchange, and emerging technologies on the future development of production, distribution, and consumption of popular music worldwide.

title: Entrepreneurship in the Creative Industries
description: The concept of “creative industry” was proposed by the Labor Party in the U.K. in 1997. It refers to the activities that are embedded in individuals’ creativities, talents and skills, which have the potential for employment opportunities and economic growth through the exploitation of intellectual properties. Creative industry has become a key area in contemporary cultural policies. This course introduces students to the basic knowledge of managing entrepreneurship, which is a key issue in the creative industries. It comprises three parts. The first part provides a general introduction. The second part discusses the nature of entrepreneurship in creative industries and demonstrates the entrepreneurial process, through which, creative ideas are generated, cultural diffusion is stimulated and innovation processes are carried out. It informs students of the key traits of the creative entrepreneurs and the business opportunities and models for entrepreneurship processes in the creative industries. In the third part, it explores the conducive policy conditions to support and encourage entrepreneurship in creative industries.
outcome: By the end of this course, a student will:  i) Have their understanding being deepened about creative industries and entrepreneurship ii) Value and appreciate entrepreneurial spirits in the creative industries  iii) Develop sets of skills for entrepreneurial practices  iv) Understand the policy conditions for entrepreneurship and acquire consultation skills for the government
syllabus: Part 1: General Introduction  Lecture 1: Creative industries and entrepreneurship: A brief introduction The first lecture in this course will brief the concept of “creative industry” and introduce the key issues of creative industries (e.g., its developmental path, the main traits and its importance to economic growth). Entrepreneurship is a concept key to creative industry development: the creation of new business ventures and the conditions that define corporate venturing will be discussed.  Readings:  CCPR, 2003, 13-26; Harley et. al., 2013, 58-61  Lecture 2: Key issues for stakeholders in the creative industries: A global perspective The development of the creative economy is widely concerned by policymakers, regional and local government and the business community. This section will explore how stakeholders face these issues in creative industries. It will also introduce creative industry development and entrepreneurship in Asia.  Readings:  Ghosh and Malloy, 2011, 12-15; Hui, 2007, 9-29  Part 2: The Entrepreneurial Process  Lecture 3: Cultural diffusion in creative industries Entrepreneurs always face the challenge of transforming their good ideas into entrepreneurial practices. This section will exemplify this process using cases in different creative sectors in Hong Kong. It will explore the issue of “cultural diffusion” in the creative economy, a process, in which, creativity is produced and disseminated among the audience. The affecting factors (e.g., identity, creative product, business process and technology) will be looked into.  Readings:  Desai, 2011, 109-130; Wolf, 1999, 45-61  Lecture 4: Innovation processes Innovation is not equal entrepreneurship, but it could be critical to successful entrepreneurship. This section discusses the scope of innovation, which transforms technical ideas and knowledge into new products or services or production processes. It uses examples of opera concert and film industry to demonstrate the process of innovation.  Readings:  Vickery, 1997, 177-179; Davis and Scase, 2000, 1-22; Hetcher, 2011, 70-80  Lecture 5: Entrepreneurship features of creative entrepreneurs  What are the characteristics of creative entrepreneurs? To be successful in creative entrepreneurship, you need to know yourself first. Creative entrepreneurs display the traits different from managers in traditional industrial sectors; they represent the new knowledge workers with creative minds and risk taking spirits. Creative entrepreneurs need to remove the barriers of artistic, economic and marketing considerations. Cases from music industry and film industry will be used to illustrate the issues.  Readings:  Malloy, 2011, 15-18; Glick, 2008, 73-80  Lecture 6: Exploring business opportunities and models for entrepreneurship  Creative products are delivered on two levels: artists and creative entrepreneurs on the one level; and the state and state entrepreneurship on the other level. This section explores how artists and entrepreneurs are fused, and examines business models for entrepreneurship in media and design industries.  Readings:  Bruin, 2007, 87-106;  Harris and Wegg-Prosser, 2009, 229-248  Lecture 7: Guest lecture: The experience from the industries  One or two guest speakers will be invited from the creative industries to share with the students their entrepreneurial experiences. Students are urged to ask questions and observe the qualities and characteristics of these creative entrepreneurs.   Part 3: Supporting Entrepreneurship in Creative Industry Sectors  Lecture 8: Investment and funding for creative enterprises  This section explores the mechanisms and barriers to creative industries investment. It will also discuss the role of the public sector and the opportunities for problem solving. Partnership, commitment, specialism and genericism are the components that constitute the landscape of investment. This section illustrates the policy context and elaborates the value chain of creative industries investment. A set of tips are provided at the end.  Readings:  Powell, 2010, 175-184; Fleming, 2007, 107-126  Lecture 9: The synergies of higher education, enterprise and innovation Universities link creativity to intellectual property and business opportunities. Knowledge spills over from education and R&D programmes at universities and supports creative entrepreneurship in the surrounding community. This section looks at the developing role of universities in the creative industries. It explores various learning and entrepreneurial models for technological innovation and business engagement at universities.  Readings:  Brooks, 1997, 109-129; Stefik and Stefik, 2010, 17-26  Lecture 10: Human language technologies in the creative industries  Two main technologies in the creative industries, i.e., information and communication technology (ICT) and human language technologies (HLT), are introduced. The key knowledge regards how these language technologies foster entrepreneurship in creative industries. Their practical implications to the creative industries in Hong Kong will be discussed. Readings:  UNTAD, 2010; Mitchell, 2016, 4-15  Lecture 11: Incubating entrepreneurship in creative industry clusters Apart from funding investment, legal protection, technological support and university education, creative industry parks serve as incubators for entrepreneurship in the creative industries. An umbrella concept to be discussed in this section is the “creative milieu,” which is often exemplified by “creative industry parks.” Their characteristics and the central management of the parks in supporting entrepreneurship will be examined.  Readings:  CCPR, 2003, 75-184; Mommaas, 2004, 507-532; Maskell, 2000, 1-6; Scott, 1997, 73-80  Fieldtrip: Visiting creative policy makers A fieldtrip will be organized to expose students to the government officials at the Innovation and Technology Bureau. It will help them to understand Hong Kong creative industry policies and the intellectual property law.   Lecture 13: Course summary In the last section, students will deliver their group presentations for feedback and discussion. An overview of the key knowledge in this course will be provided and practical implications will be discussed.

title: Curating and Managing Arts Festival
description: With a global growing interest in organizing grand scale arts and cultural activities to attract local and overseas audience, arts festivals have become popular urban cultural events for cultural development and for building the reputation of a city. Curating and managing cultural festival is subsequently an important area of studies in cultural management. Curating and managing arts festival is a complex process that requires creative programming, skillful execution and careful financial control. This course not only studies the mode of operations of various types of cultural festivals, including festivals of performing arts, visual arts, film, literary arts and community festive celebration, but also introduces to students the basic skills and knowledge of curating and managing arts festivals, with references to local and overseas examples.
outcome: - Understand the operation format, management process in organizing various types of cultural festivals; - Have the ability to curate and coordinate programmes within a specific arts/cultural festival; - Learn the supporting skills for successful implementation of arts/cultural festival, including publicity, marketing, public safety, security and finance control; - Equip students with the critical skills to review and evaluate the success and failure of a major cultural event.
syllabus: 1. Cultural Festival: an introduction  This session studies the history, social functions and basic modes of operation of cultural festivals, with examples from Hong Kong and fromvarious parts of the world.  2. Various types of festivals and their distinctive characters  This session introduces various types of arts festival, from festivals focusing on specific media, grand scale multi-disciplinary festivals, to community based religious/celebrative events, with emphasis on studying their own distinctive characteristics and special technical requirements.  3. Planning cultural festival 1:  This session focuses on programme planning and coordination, as well as resource management within the institutional and community context.  4. Planning festival 2:  This session deals with the planning of setting up an operation framework, allocation of manpower, design of the technical support and working out an operational schedule for a major arts festival.  5. Planning festival 3:  Funding is an essential part of organizing cultural festivals. This session studies the various ways to seek public and private fund, and ways to do financial planning and to exercise financial control over the running of projects.  6. Planning festival 4:  In addition to curating and implementing programmes, a successful festival also includes much supporting activities, ranging from marketing to educational events. This session focuses on the studies of these supplementary activities in order to get the best results for an arts event.  7. Presentation and discussion Students are asked to form groups to work on proposals for an arts festival. Students are to do their representations at class, and engage in discussion after the presentations.  8. Curation and programming This session studies the curation of festival programmes with references to local cultural strength and needs, the use of available resources, as well as a study of the global trends in arts festival.  9. Execution and crisis management This session studies the security measure for major cultural events, and preparations required for unexpected incidents and crisis.   10. Case studies Using the Hong Kong Arts Festival and Hong Kong Film Festival for case studies, this session studies the actual implementation of cultural festivals within the specific social, cultural and financial context of Hong Kong.  11. Evaluation and research The success of a festival depends heavily on responses from the audience, the press and the public, this session studies the application of marketing strategies and its consequent results, and ways to make meaningful evaluation for future development.  12. Critical issues relating to arts festival As arts and cultural festivals become increasingly prolific, its social and cultural impacts are not to be underestimated. This session takes on a critical review of the impacts, the pro and con of organizing arts festivals, as well as possible alternatives.  13. Review and discussion This session reviews the entire course and engages students in an over-all discussion.

title: Interpretation of Heritage
requirements: Not for students who have taken CUMT3009 or CUMT4101 or CURE4411.
description: Cultural heritage is a dynamic and evolving concept that encompasses various interpretations rather than being a fixed notion. It includes a wide range of perspectives, from Eurocentric to post-colonial, with an increasing focus on living culture that intertwines global and local narratives. This field involves diverse interpretive lenses, public discourse, human rights issues, and a shift from mere observation to immersive experiences. The interpretations of cultural heritage are shaped by numerous stakeholders, including educators, public program participants, researchers, writers, designers, creatives, consultants, curators, scientists, and historians. In recent years, technological advancements have further enhanced the use of digital media and social networking in cultural heritage, fostering new connections between visitors and heritage. Consequently, the interpretation of cultural heritage remains dynamic and fluid, embracing a variety of approaches and philosophies.This course aims to provide students with a broad knowledge of cultural heritage interpretations and the theoretical frameworks that offer different lenses and approaches for thinking about cultural heritage. It covers various types of cultural heritage, the role of storytelling in heritage interpretation, heritage as public discourse, identity issues, visitor engagement and education, tourism, community involvement, and ethical issues. Additionally, this course will examine how technology plays a role in engaging audiences and facilitating interpretations. By offering students diverse concepts of cultural heritage interpretations, they will gain a comprehensive understanding of current interpretive approaches, emerging trends, and innovations in the interpretation of heritage.

title: Museum Studies
requirements: Not for students who have taken CUMT3108 or ANTH4720 or HIST5514
description: Museums have multiple roles in a society. They are academic institutes and public arenas for education. In the broad term, they represent national culture and communal heritage. This course leads students to understand museum exhibitions and management within social contexts. The lectures respond to the following issues:1. What are the functions and achievements of museum activities?2. In what ways can we understand and learn from an exhibition? What are the essential elements of museum catalogues and cultural writing?3. How do museum workers balance both marketing and social needs?4. In what ways can we participate in the operation of a museum?The course draws discussions from both the perspectives of museum workers and visitors. Some current issues concerning the roles of museums are also covered.

title: Global Cultural Theories
description: Departing from the dominant canon of critical theory, this course aims to introduce students to a wider, more diverse range of theoretical texts and frameworks by marginalized voices and from peripheral locations.This course seeks to decolonize theory by multiplying the sites of intellectual and critical inquiry. Instead of treating Benjamin, Adorno, Hall, and Grossberg as representative of the corpus of theory, it engages with prevailing discussions in Postcolonial Studies, Modernity/Coloniality, and Black Studies. It moves beyond the call for ‘de-Westernization’ by looking at theoretical texts and frameworks produced in Asia, Africa, and Latin America. The course concludes by exploring work about indigeneity, memory, and environmentalism. The course is designed for advanced undergraduates with familiarity in critical approaches to literature, cinema, art, and media. Classes will grapple with the following questions: What qualifies as theory? Is theory necessarily abstract? What is the relationship of theory to particularity and difference? How can theory be made more attune to its contexts of production, dissemination, and application? How can film and visual art offer sources for theorizing? How might theoretical frameworks respond more significantly to social, economic, and environmental conditions from the restructuring of the capitalist system, expansion of media networks, dissolution of national borders, and deterioration of the climate crisis?
outcome: The objectives are:   To become acquainted with theoretical texts and frameworks in Cultural Studies by marginalized voices from different peripheral social and geographic contexts To apply theory to analyze the articulation of race, gender, memory, and nature in literature, cinema, art, and media To formulate, develop, write, and revise an original critical essay using global cultural theories

title: Graduation Thesis
description: This course provides an opportunity for students to undertake supervised study on a selected topic of interest. Students will be led to examine aspects of the selected topic, conduct a critical literature review and a systematic investigation of the topic they have chosen. Students are required to regularly discuss with the teacher concrete findings in their research and submit written progress reports as scheduled by the teacher and a complete project report at the end of the term.
outcome: 1.Apply theory critically to analyse cultural texts they interested. 2.Use a self-reflective approach to devising and developing an academic paper. 3.Reflectively evaluate their learning and personal planning processes.
syllabus: 1) Students have to schedule regular meetings with their supervisor to discuss the findings of their research. 2)Students have to submit a written progress report on or before the deadline.

title: Time, Space, and Identity in World Cinema
description: This course aims to introduce you to a range of films from world cinema that illuminate the ways in which cinema as an art-form and a cultural product has engaged with issues of space, time and identity and reformulated our very experience of these arenas. It uses a range of critical frameworks to enable you to understand how the study of film can reconfigure understandings of space and its cultural production; temporality, speed and the practice of everyday life; and the representation of bodies as having a particular gender, race and sexuality.

title: Critical Approaches to Pornography
components:
Field Studies/Field-trip
Laboratory
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
description: The course will offer an introduction to critical views on pornography, which is defined as sexually explicit media within different cinematic traditions and digital screen cultures. The aim of the course is to show that pornography is a not a unified screen culture but consists of varied representations within cultural contexts. The course will teach students how to analyze these representations and how to take into account their cultural histories. The course will take a Cultural Studies approach and examine within specific cultural environments and include the positions of anti-porn and pro-porn activists. Therefore students will get an overview of diverging perspectives while being encouraged to consider their own values and critical responses. Students will be asked to respond to theories and audio-visual examples, while actively partaking in debates about pornography and its impact on religion, gender, sexuality, health, labor and economy. Finally, the course will pay special importance to how contemporary sexually explicit media are impacting new user groups such young adult netizens, female consumers, disabled people, as well as ethnic and sexual minorities. Students will carry out a major assignment while learning how to apply ethnographic research methods to analyze representations of the body and sexuality within screen cultures. In this assignment, they will focus on a media environment/platform and a sexual culture of their choice to find out how culture is being redefined and visualized by media users. Two workshops will be organized in the media lab in order to train the students in different methods and perspectives on digital ethnographyLanguage of instruction: Classes and assignments will be carried out in the English language and students’ active participation in both lectures and tutorials will be required. Students can carry out ethnographic fieldwork in Cantonese or any language of your choice, but need to present the results in English.Learning Activities: Students are required to attend a 3-hour class each week. The course combines theoretical lectures with the viewing of films and media examples. There will also be tutorial sessions each week based on the lectures and on the weekly readings. All students are required to post weekly reflections on Blackboard and to participate in discussions. In addition to the weekly readings and reflections, students will conduct research and planning for their assessments and oral presentations independently and in groups.Please be advised that this course will involve some screenings and discussions of sexually explicit materials and category III films. Therefore, students under 18 years-old are advised not to take this course.

title: Film Classics: Aesthetics and Politics
description: This course aims at introducing some of the major film classics from America (Hollywood), Europe (France and Italy), Japan, and China produced from the earliest era to circa 1960. They will be viewed and studied in a cultural and historical context, together with detailed analysis of their form and content in order to understand their "canonical" status. Basic film theories - especially those dealing with film genres and film "auteurs" - will also be used.

title: Workshop in Creative Content
description: Through workshops, this course aims to cultivate students' creative thinking and abilities of artistic expression. It leads students to explore various art forms, such as graphics, sound, non-fiction narrative, drama, experimental film, and cross/inter-disciplinary arts, etc. Specific projects are planned and executed around particular themes through primarily teacher-student consultations and discussions supplemented by lectures. It helps students grasp creative skills to express their opinions and emotions effectively using audiovisual elements. This advanced practical course requires students to have completed the foundational course CURE2066 Visual Design Foundation in advance.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: Develop the creative and technical skills necessary to express students' opinions. Enhance the ability to appreciate and think critically about various forms of artistic works while developing the critical, analytical, and editing skills necessary to evaluate works in progress, both in the student's own projects and those of their peers. Improve students' communication and teamwork skills. Learn how to showcase works and develop the ability to engage in dialogues with society.

title: Arts, Propaganda and Social Action
description: The course studies the history, theories and techniques of organizing cultural activities for social and political causes. It investigates the relationship between cultural expressions and the infrastructure of power, and the application of arts and culture for social, political actions, covering such major movements from the avant-garde of the 19th Century, the USSR and the Chinese propaganda movements, to the arts for civil right movements since 1960s. Case studies of similar movements in Hong Kong will also be included. The final part of the course will introduce to students the operational and managerial skill required for organizing such cultural activities.

title: Digital Imaging, Book Production and Contemporary Arts
description: This course will teach the conceptual foundations and implement the use of practices of digital imaging and book production okmaking within contemporary arts. The course will also teach aspects of contemporary art and photography as a documentary and conceptual medium. It will focus on digital imaging’s ability to enhance existing literature, and reproduce or manipulate pre-existing images. Students will be expected to equally apply digital imaging applications in a technically adept and creative manner with an eye towards given art historical movements and examples such as Dada and Surrealism.The course will be based on software instruction, as well as use of digital scanning, digital photography and video productions . Assignments will include (but not be limited to) desktop publishing for the making of artist books, catalogues “zines” (inexpensive DIY magazines) and e-books that are consumed on various digital media format such websites, mobile phones and i-pad tablets.

title: Documentary Studies: Theories and Practices
description: The course explores the history and basic theory of documentary film. General concepts, aesthetics, ethics and different forms of documentary will be introduced as well. The aim of it is to help students develop a critical understanding and appreciation of documentary through lecture, screening, practical workshop and experience of creating a film. It also helps them to know how to discover and represent the cultural phenomenon in daily life by using visual method. Students are expected to finish their short documentary films at the end of the semester.
outcome: To equip students with general knowledge of the concepts and the history of documentary film.  • To analyze the close connection between history, culture, and cinema in documentary film.   • Students will understand how to conceive, shoot and edit a documentary.  • To use digital media as a tool in research and as a method of presenting research outcomes.

title: Summer Internship
description: Process of cultural production and cultural practices at various levels are essential to the training of cultural sensitivity and analysis in cultural studies. This course aims to provide students with on-site experience of cultural production and practices for their reflection and integration of cultural theories and concepts they learnt in regular classes. Students will be introduced to a range of cultural institutions and culture-related non-governmental organizations for a placement of eight weeks between May to July during summer. Students will be asked to attend several sessions of orientations and evaluation before and during their placement.
outcome: Objectives:  Provide learning and practicing opportunities for students
syllabus: 1) First meeting with all year 2 students 2) Final submission date for the internship application 3) Matching students with partner institutions 4) Group interview with applicants 5) Finalize the results of internship allocation 6) Internship starts 7) Meeting & sharing session I 8) Meeting & sharing session II 9) Submission of written report by students 10) Submission of evaluation report by institutions

title: AI, Arts and Technology
description: What is the big deal about computational technologies for the arts? This course explores the evolution, current state, and future implications of artificial intelligence (AI) in art and media. This course provides an overview of the history of AI and computation from Norbert Wiener’s Cybernetics to OpenAI’s ChatGPT. Besides concepts, students will explore the theories of art and technology through field trips and practices. Although history and critique are central to this course, students will also gain some hands-on experience in applications of AI in art. This course includes lectures, projects, and critical discussions. At the end of the course, students will be able to critically evaluate the inevitable integration of AI in creative workflows and its implications for the future of art, and articulate the critical issues and ethical implications of AI on creative arts.

title: Chan School of Buddhism
description: The Chan movement has been described by Hu Shih as a reformation or revolution in Buddhism and by Suzuki as a movement in which the Chinese mind completely asserted itself, in a sense, in opposition to the Indian mind. This course examines the Chan movement from a historical perspective. Attention will also be paid to the study of basic scriptures of the Chan School of Buddhism.

title: Selected Taoist Classics
description: This course consists of reading of the classical literature of Taoism formulated in its early phase of development. Students are trained to understand Taoism through original textual reading. Selections include the T'ai-ping ching, the Pao-p'u tzu, the Chen-kao, and the Laotzu Hsiang-erh chu.

title: Senior Seminar
description: This course is to be taken by senior students who are required to write, under guidance and supervision, a thesis with the aim of integrating various areas of studies in theology and religion. Students will be evaluated on the ability to reflect upon major theological and religious issues.
outcome: After completion of the course, students are able to: • Perform basic research in the library; • Use various techniques for gathering information (such as interviews, observation, literature review) • Formulate a clear thesis statement; • Organize ideas logically and effectively to support the thesis statement; • Present unified and coherent support for the thesis statement; • Demonstrate effective editorial skills.

title: Integrated Studies in Cultural Management
description: This course is continuation of CUMT1001, Introduction to Cultural Management, and looks at cultural management from the macro perspective. Successful culture managers work to maintain healthy balance between culture and its relevant fields of interests, which sometimes could turn harmful or beneficial to the growth and development of the corresponding cultural area. The first session discusses the mutual dependence between culture and various areas, which include laws, economy, community, national interests, and art practitioners. In practice, cultural managers usually have to conform to the values and ethnics of the corresponding countries. For that reason, the second session will look at the approach taken in a few remarkable examples, which Taiwan, China, Singapore, South Korea, U.K., and the U.S.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to explain different national and social concerns for preserving culture; to identify the legal and ethnic issues relevant to cultural productions; to identify marketing strategies in cultural promotion; to evaluate the measures for maximizing the input of art practitioners; and to describe the various successful cultural schemes implemented in overseas countries.
syllabus: Section I: Culture in Context   1. Culture & States The growth of cultural industries is strongly related to political environment and state policy. This lecture discusses the tension and mutual expectations between cultural workers and politicians. It will use the experience of the European Union and the US as examples.   2. Culture & Laws Over the last few decades, there were a number of remarkable disputes over international art transactions and copy rights. Given the growing size of the art market, knowledge about the previous cases is essential. This lecture takes the examples taken from the US for discussions.   3. Culture & UNESCO UNESCO is arguably a rising new power in forming a standard for evaluating cultural heritage of different nations. This lecture discusses the roles of UNESCO and its work in different cultural disciplines. National disputes over ownership of World Heritage sites will be bought up.   4. Culture & Community Nowadays many nations and countries perceive culture and heritage as means to empower developing communities. This lecture discusses the conservation of indigenous or minorities cultures, and its impacts on the majority population of the same community.   5. Culture & Marketing  Culture and business are often taken as two contrasting disciplines. One of the key issues in cultural management is to develop cultural audience with both education and economic concerns. Religious sectors are a growing body of cultural venues for tourism and heritage management. This lecture discusses the debated concerns about conducting marketing or business-driven strategies in cultural and religious areas.   Section II: Case Studies 6. Cultural Management in Taiwan Taiwan provides an excellent example to demonstrate the top-down organization of heritage sites. This lecture reviews a series of campaigns launched in Taiwan during the past twenty years, and discusses the reasons that may have contributed to engage the mass of Taiwan into different aspects of cultural industries.   7. Cultural Management in China China represents many upcoming opportunities in cultural management. This lecture reviews some recent moves: rapid establishment of museums, growing number of commercial galleries and auction houses, rise of new Confucian schools, introduction of university degrees in cultural management, etc. The lecture discusses the consuming force underneath the cultural growth in the Mainland.   8. Cultural Management in Singapore During the last two decades, the government of Singapore invested heavily on constructing cultural venues for both national and economic purposes. This lecture gives an overview of their establishment and invites students to reflect on the opportunities found in other areas of Asia.   9. Cultural Management in South Korea This lecture discusses the contemporary cultural policies undertaken in South Korea. During the last decade, South Korea featured an economic miracle in Asia by rejuvenating the distressed financial market with cultural developments, which included the film industry, heritage protection, publication, and cultural tourism.   10. Cultural Management in UK The United Kingdom was one of the earliest countries that invested heavily on promotion of cultural and arts events. This lecture gives a short history of the early developments made in the UK after the Second World War, and discusses the recent campaigns undertaken to break the boundaries between high arts and popular culture.   11. Cultural Management in USA The United States distinguishes herself from all other countries by boosting the absence of a ministry for arts and culture, yet artists and cultural workers receive due respects for their contributions. This lecture looks at the case of the US and examines her success in cultural management.   12. Group presentation This lecture is taken as a mock symposium for students to present their group projects and make comments on those by their peers. The presentation will be evaluated against the clarity and thoughts over the approved topics.   13. Conclusion: What is the best for Hong Kong?  This last session will summarize the topics covered throughout the course. Hong Kong is facing the challenge that many aspects of cultural developments in relation to urban planning, legislation, economy, national identity, and education are all pending. This lecture is an open discussion for students to brainstorm the possible approaches that Hong Kong could take in years to come.

title: Culture-led City Development
description: This course aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the culture-led city development phenomenon and equip them with the protocols for execution and practice. It comprises three blocks: Block 1 unfolds an overall picture of the phenomenon, introduces the related concepts, displays the disciplinary foundation of this topic, traces its history, and discusses the rationales and developing tendency. Block 2 studies the urban sociological and economic approaches employed in developing the theoretical foundation, highlighting a transition in capitalist production mode and urban governance upheld by public-private partnership modes. Criticisms are also presented to complete a dialectic mindset of this phenomenon. With a strong practical dimension, Block 3 teaches students various methods to make consultancy and policy recommendations for culture-led urban development projects. A variety of practices that constitute the culture-led strategy are discussed, such as how to plan for a creative city and cultural facilities, how to boost creative industries and develop cultural quarters and creative clusters, as well as how to revitalize historic quarters.

title: Heritage and Modern Applications
requirements:
1. Pre-requisites: CUMT3009 Interpreting Chinese Antiquities or CURE3409 Interpretation of Heritage or its equivalence
2. Not for students who have taken CUMT4004.
description: Cultural heritage is not confined to the past but is continuously carried forward into the present and future through various modern applications. These applications address current societal concerns, needs, and the ever-changing culture both locally and globally. The relevance of cultural heritage is influenced by complex power structures, including its presentation and representation in contexts such as postcolonialism, racial dynamics, gender, intergenerational equity, disparities in access to technology, marginalization, and the tension between localism and globalization. Additionally, the modern application of cultural heritage is shaped by evolving economic structures and technological advancements. Heritage is increasingly utilized by creative industries, with its assets digitized, interpreted, and experienced through advanced technologies such as AI and VR. Ensuring the continued relevance of cultural heritage has become a critical issue.This course aims to provide students with an understanding of cultural heritage and its diverse modern applications, along with the critical concepts that shape our perception of its relevance today. It addresses issues concerning cultural heritage and its relationship with changing urban demographics, climate change, intergenerational equity, and the application of technologies for future alternatives. Additionally, the course explores cultural heritage as an economic generator, its role in performance, sports, and games, and its adoption in personalized tours and emerging cultural industries. Through a variety of concepts and case studies, students will gain multiple perspectives on current practices and reflect on the vast potential of cultural heritage in contemporary times.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students would be able to:   Explore key examples of cultural heritage and its diverse modern applications, along with the critical concepts that shape our perception of its relevance today. Understand the modern applications of cultural heritage. Explain cases where cultural heritage acts as an economic generator. Reflect on broader critical issues surrounding the modern applications of cultural heritage, including but not limited to postcolonialism, racial dynamics, and other related topics. Cultivate an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions within existing applications and projecting future directions in cultural heritage.
