title: Advanced Museum Studies
requirements:
1. Pre-requisite(s): CUMT3108 Museum Studies or CURE3508 Museum Studies
2. Not for students who have taken CUMT4008.
description: This course picks up topics, which cannot be fully covered in CUMT4007 Museum Studies, but are essential for students pursuing careers in the area of museum and exhibition planning. This course is an advanced version, because it will touch on debated issues regarding museums. It focuses on installation, display, and site management. The purposes of the course may be summarized as follows: 1. What are the various display methods in museums? What are the concerns involved in selecting the ‘right’ ones? 2. How are museum workers (non-curatorial) trained? 3. What are the essential facilities a museum is expected to have? Why? 4. What is the role of museum in the contemporary arts, which is the area of debate regarding its significance and curatorship? The course develops students’ awareness towards global developments in world-class museums, so that they are equipped with skills and knowledge necessary for long-term competition in museums or other cultural institutions.
outcome: At the end of the course, students should be able to:  1. Analyze exhibition display methods and theories.  2. Think critically about display and social concerns.  3. Clarify the roles and potentials of museum workers.  4. Get prepared for career related to management of museums and cultural industries.
syllabus: 1. Introduction: the Unseen Impacts of Museums  Museums make impacts in our societies in many ways, but they are usually gone unnoticed, almost unseen. What are the popular ways taken to measure the impacts of museums? And how useful (and meaningful) are they?  Readings: a. Paulus, Odile. "Measuring Museum Performance: A Study of Museums in France and the United States." International Journal of Arts Management 6, no. 1 (October 1, 2003): 50-63. b. Jacobsen, John W. Measuring museum impact and performance theory and practice (Chapters 2&3). Lanham: Rowman & Littlefield, 2016. PART I Display and Installation 2. Oral Histories I Not everything in the museum is tangible. In many cases, the objects are reminders of something unheard, unseen, or even almost forgotten. Oral histories are a common way to preserve the dying records. This lecture introduces the practice of building oral history records, and get students to develop their set of questions to preserve extinguishing cultural practices or knowledge.  Reading: a. Barnes, Lindsey; Guise, Kim. "World War Words: The Creation of a World War II–Specific Vocabulary for the Oral History Collection at The National WWII Museum." The Oral History Review 40, no. 1 (2013): 126-34. b. Chew, R. "Collected stories - The rise of oral history in museum exhibitions." Museum News 81, no. 6 (Nov. & dec. 2002): 30-37.   3. Oral Histories II  With audio and written records readily made, how do we put them in the museum setting? This lecture discusses various possibilities and gets students to develop the rationale of their selections through debates and discussions.  Reading: a. Jones, Sian. "Oral History and Museum Education." Oral History 12, no. 2 (October 1, 1984): 68-71. b. Green, Anna. "Returning History to the Community: Oral History in a Museum Setting." The Oral History Review 24, no. 2 (December 1, 1997): 53-72. 4. Sound I: Installation of Performance If the intangible cultural heritage is something as abstract as live performance, the elements of living people inputs are unavoidable. The practices and theories regarding the staging of a live show in the museum setting are hinged on the issue of authenticity. How much control does a curator have over the accuracy of the performance?  Reading: a. Pollock, Della, ed. Exceptional spaces: essays in performance and history (Chapter 1&2). Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 1998. b. Niblett, Hannah; Allison, Jennifer. "Performance as interpretation: a museum studies perspective." Research in Drama Education: The Journal of Applied Theatre and Performance 21, no. 4 (October 1, 2016): 574-80. c. Cox, Michelle A. "Intermedial museum performance: a reflection on the use of intermedial performance as a medium of immersion at the Barbados Museum & Historical Society." Research in Drama Education: The Journal of Applied Theatre and Performance 21, no. 3 (July 2, 2016): 349-54. 5. Sound II: Installation of Music  Musical instruments are valuable museum objects, because they embodied the appreciation of music and the meticulous knowledge in physics and mathematics too. In a gallery as quiet as in a museum, how do we deliver or reconstruct ‘music’ for present-day enjoyment?  Readings: Gillespie, Kirsty. "Musical Landscapes of Lihir: Exploring performance and place in a museum exhibition." Perfect Beat 17, no. 1 (2016): 9-24. PART II Auxiliary devices 6. Use of Videos  Showing a clip in the middle of the exhibition is a common practice. What are the conventions in so doing? What are the advantages and limits of applying animations and other digital devices?  Reading: a. George, Judith; Stevenson, Anne. "Structured video recall: a museum application." British Journal of Educational Technology 22, no. 3 (September 1991): 203-09. b. Bakken, Sven Magne ; Pierroux, Palmyre. "Framing a topic: Mobile video tasks in museum learning." Learning, Culture and Social Interaction 5 (June 2015): 54-65. 7. Use of Dioramas  Dioramas are most useful in the area of Natural Science, because the extinguished animals and plants are best represented through live reconstructions. Historical museums often employ diorama to highlight the visiting experience.  Reading: a. Knutson, Karen; Lyon, Mandela ; Crowley, Kevin ; Giarratani, Lauren. "Flexible Interventions to Increase Family Engagement at Natural History Museum Dioramas." Curator: The Museum Journal 59, no. 4 (October 2016): 339-52. b. Gambini, Annastella ; Pezzotti, Antonella ; Broglia, Alfredo ; Poli, Annamaria. " The Digital Diorama Project: The Design." Procedia - Social and Behavioral Sciences 182 (May 13, 2015): 470-76. 8. Use of Miscellaneous Objects  Not all objects are substantial or significant enough to be regarded as attractive. In fact, a number of museums nowadays are overflowed with objects of low historical values. How may we put them up in the gallery to complete the storyline, while not violating the boundary of over-interpretation?  Readings Hess, M.; Robson, S. "3D imaging for museum artefacts: A portable test object for heritage and museum documentation of small objects." International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences - ISPRS Archives 39 (2012): 103-08. PART III Museum Competitive Strategies 9. The ‘Branch’ Strategy  Gugong (The Palace Museum) is going to set up a branch in Hong Kong. The branch strategy, however, is not a new thing. It began in the 1980s, when a number of century-old museums considered expansion and revenue-raising. This lecture reviews the many successful and unsuccessful cases in the past. What may be the risks for the new branch of Gugong in Hong Kong?  Readings: a. Sai Hua. " Analysis of the impact of the major museums in Asia." Culturas 2, no. 2 (November 1, 2015): 49-68. b. Gill, Chris. "Beijing and Taipei aim to overcome historic divide." Art Newspaper 20, no. 220 (January 2011): 22. 10. Training I: museum curatorial workers In-house trainings on a routine basis are an useful way to develop a coherent staff team. We will test the usefulness of the training package as suggested by ICOM and reflect on its rationale to run the museum as incorporation.  UNESCO Running a Museum: A Practical Handbook, available online. 11. Training II: museum non-curatorial workers Curators are usually not the first person a visitor sees or gets in touch with in the museum. There are receptionists, volunteers, security guards, caretakers, cafe waiters, etc. These people are parts of the museum. Together their bonding represents the brand of the museum. This lecture will again use the ICOM package and check the training programmes suggested in there. UNESCO Running a Museum: A Practical Handbook, available online. 12. Museum Facilities  Cloakrooms, washrooms, disabled facilities, restaurants, and rest areas are essential in a museum nowadays. There is also the space outside the museum building. What are the potentials of fully utilizing those space for the purpose of building a coherent institution?  Readings: a. Gofman, Ale; Moskowitz, Howard R.; Mets, Tõnis. "Marketing Museums and Exhibitions: What Drives the Interest of Young People." Journal of Hospitality Marketing & Management 20, no. 6 (August 1, 2011): 601-618. b. Del Chiappa, Giacomo; Andreu, Luisa; G. Gallarza, Martina. "Emotions and visitors' satisfaction at a museum." International Journal of Culture, Tourism and Hospitality Research 8, no. 4 (2014): 420-31. c. Del Chiappa, Giacomo; Ladu, Maria Gabriela; Meleddu, Marta; Pulina, Manuela. "Investigating the degree of visitors' satisfaction at a museum." Anatolia 24, no. 1 (April 1, 2013): 52-62.  13. The Mass Produced Gifts at Gift Shops  Coffee mugs, magnets, coasters, keychains, and many other mass produced objects are often found in the gift shops. The museums of China even develop online shop through the largest online shopping website. Are we tired of them yet? Let’s discuss the potential risks in the over-flooding gift shops. Is there a way out other than contracting a design company to produce goods of similar types and forms?  Readings: a. Jud, Brian. "Sell More Books to Non-Bookstore Retailers." title: Special Topics in Heritage Management
description: Cultural institutions such as museums, archives, and cultural centers play a critical role in the preservation, interpretation, and dissemination of heritage. Through diverse programs, place-making projects, and cultural policies, these institutions preserve and represent cultural memory, sustain community identity and continuity, and emphasize the importance of community involvement and participatory approaches. They ensure that both tangible and intangible heritage are accessible to the public and future generations. Additionally, they intersect with contemporary issues such as the impact of globalization, tourism, the role of policy-making and advocacy in heritage protection, and the influence of the digital age on cultural heritage.This course aims to provide students with both analytical and practical skills in managing cultural heritage, with a particular emphasis on intangible heritage, which includes oral histories, performative rituals, social practices, and craftsmanship. Students will engage with diverse topics, exploring how the principles and practices of heritage management inform a variety of theories and approaches, such as cultural relativism, ethnocentrism, and post-colonial theory. By focusing on a chosen area of cultural heritage or a particular field of heritage theory, this course will equip students with the ability to reflect on the challenges and opportunities presented by historical and current phenomena and to participate in projects with the potential to impact individuals and societies.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to: Explain key historical and contemporary examples of cultural heritage projects, relating them to broader local and global contexts. Examine critical issues concerning the ways different methods of preservation, interpretation, and dissemination of heritage adopted by cultural institutions. Develop skills to critically analyze intangible heritage, including oral histories, performative rituals, social practices, and craftsmanship. Acquire personal and social competencies related to various forms of culture and become an active agent in managing cultural heritage. Foster an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions within existing methods of preservation, interpretation, and dissemination of heritage.

title: Special Topics in Curation
description: Curating in art and culture involves selecting and organizing artworks, cultural artifacts, practices, and narratives to create a cohesive exhibition that conveys a specific theme. This requires a deep understanding of the artists' intentions, the works' context, and diverse cultural expressions, as well as a commitment to preserving heritage and promoting dialogue. Curators play a crucial role in ensuring representation, authenticity, and inclusivity in the audience's experience. In recent years, the concept of curating has extended to social media, where it involves strategically choosing and presenting content to engage a digital audience. This includes managing visuals, texts, and interactive elements to create a compelling online presence. The term "curating," once limited to museums, now applies broadly, reflecting the growing importance of thoughtful content curation in effectively engaging and informing diverse audiences across various platforms. This course aims to provide students with both analytical and practical skills in curation. Students will engage with diverse topics, exploring how various platforms offer unique opportunities for curators to select, organize, manage, and create artworks, artifacts, content, and knowledge. By covering various curatorial strategies in the ever-expanding field of knowledge production, this course will equip students with the ability to reflect on current phenomena and curate projects that have the potential to impact individuals and societies.

title: Special Topics in Cultural Institutions
description: Cultural institutions are organizations that preserve, promote, and disseminate culture, knowledge, and heritage. These institutions can take various forms, ranging from museums, libraries, archives, and galleries to virtual and tech-based platforms. The evolution of cultural institutions reflects broader changes in cultural management models and organizational modes, influenced by ever-changing technology and societal shifts. From traditional museums, libraries, and archives to innovative digital and participatory models, cultural institutions are increasingly leveraging diverse approaches to enhance accessibility, engagement, and cultural impact.This course aims to provide students with both analytical and practical skills in managing cultural institutions. Students will engage with diverse topics, exploring how various models and organizational modes within different types of cultural institutions inform a variety of theories and practices. By focusing on a chosen institutional form or specific field of cultural institutions, this course will equip students with the ability to reflect on current phenomena and participate in projects that have the potential to impact individuals and societies.

title: Special Topic in Creative Industries
description: In recent years, the rapid development of cultural and creative industries has transformed the way cultural products are created, produced and distributed. These industries, from theater and fashion to social media and game design, highlight how contemporary societies use intellectual and creative approaches to gain economic and symbolic competitiveness. Alongside technological innovations, the creative sector also plays a significant role in driving global economic transformation, offering government agencies and entrepreneurs new strategies to produce creative experiences not anticipated in the past.This course aims to provide students with both analytical and practical skills in cultural and creative industries. Students will engage with a diverse range of topics, exploring how various sectors within these industries inform a variety of theories and practices. By covering multiple creative and entrepreneurial strategies in the ever-expanding field of cultural and creative industries, this course will equip students with the ability to reflect on the current phenomenon and create projects that have the potential to impact individuals and societies.
outcome: Explain key historical and contemporary examples of creative industries, relating them to a broader local and global context Examine critical issues concerning how different cultural and economic models impact the creative industries Develop skills to critically analyze the relationship between culture, society and the economy Acquire personal and social competencies relating to the creative industries, and act as an active agent in producing creative projects Develop an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions within the creative industries

title: Introduction to Cultural Studies
description: Through examining texts, artistic forms and discursive practices that reflect and produce different cultures, students will take part in delineating the working definition(s), methodology and critical awareness of the subject. Concepts such as multiculturalism, diaspora, hybridity, globalism/localism, transnationalism will be discussed. Emphasis will be given to Hong Kong culture as a basic reference point in its contact and interaction with other cultures.
outcome: 1) Knowledge Outcomes  Basic concepts in Cultural Studies Historical developments of Cultural Studies in England and its expansion since the 1990s Critical dimensions of the concept of culture and their relevance to everyday life cultural practices, the working of cultural production and consumption  2) Skill Outcomes Independent academic research on new concepts Analytical writing on cultural concepts and approaches of cultural criticism Presenting ideas through reading and cultural analysis  3) Attitude Outcomes Proactive in learning and research

title: Introduction to Film and Screen Studies
description: This course focuses on the language and the basic theories of film/media. From formal, historical and theoretical approaches, students will learn how to analyze and critique the meaning behind the cinematic images; also, will learn to integrate one’s cinematic experience in terms of emotion and reason, and to develop one’s ability in film criticism writing. In the course of teaching, three aspects will be highlighted including the critical, functional and practical ones.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:  - identify, describe, and analyze the technical aspects of film as art.  - deeply analyze in diverse ways of critical thinking on film/media, such as the views of genre, auteurship, and spectatorship, and grasp the ways to utilize these different analytical frameworks for the writing of film criticism.

title: Special Topics in Cultural Studies
description: The specific topics of this course vary from year to year. Generally, they can be genres, systems of representation, cultural forms, issues and/or theories related to the dynamic process of interactivity among cultures. Students are allowed to take this course not more than twice, and gain the units each time they pass the course.
outcome: 1) Students are expected to develop interdisciplinary perspectives to understand and be critical of the following: Our regional, national, and global orders are made up of and maintained by cultural practices, expressions, and meanings. Cultural industries and institutions play a key role to shape our collective identity, taste, and values.  2) Students are expected to develop the following skills and values: Ability in critically analyzing the diversity of values and interests in society Ability in drawing on a number of disciplinary origins within areas of the arts, humanities and social sciences to appreciate the richness and the usefulness of interdisciplinary approach Critical awareness related to issues pertaining to gender, class, and national identities

title: Global Cultural Theories
description: The course will be an introduction to the critical discourses of cultural studies. It aims to provide students with a basic theoretical framework to the understanding and practising of cultural criticisms in contemporary society. The course will outline the theoretical propositions of major thinkers contributing to cultural studies of the last century including those of the Birmingham School, the New Left, the Frankfurt School, the psychoanalysis school, the postmodernists and poststructuralists, etc. Students will be exposed to selected classical writings of major thinkers and learn the questions and methodologies employed by them. The course will equip students with the basic knowledge and concepts in analysing the main issues and practices in cultural studies.
outcome: The objectives are: 1) to get you acquaintance with a range of theoretical approaches that you tend to come across in Cultural Studies; 2) to understand key concepts and contexts of these approaches as well as their unity and diversity; 3) to identify hotspots and issues in contemporary cultural theories for further research or following up; 4) to cultivate your confidence in making use of a broader range of theories as analytical and critical tools in Cultural Studies.

title: Islam: Religious Tradition and Modern Politics
description: This course investigates the complicated relationship between ages-old Islamic tradition and modernity as exemplified most by the rise of secular politics. We will first focus on this problematic by tracing a particular set of questions through which knowledge about Islam and Muslim politics has been produced. By reading excerpts from scholarly works and influential media outlets, by watching documentaries, and through discussions during the class, we will develop a framework in which to recognize, understand and appreciate the gamut of political predicaments that Islamic tradition and its practitioners face under modern conditions. By the end of the first half of this course, students are expected to develop the ability to engage the following questions: What kind of assumptions about Islam and politics inform popular discussions on this topic? How has the rise of modern state power shaped and reshaped Muslims’ understanding of their tradition? What forms of lives, histories and struggles can and cannot be captured by this problematic? We will then spend the last several weeks exploring case studies that are considered to be paradigmatic of Islamic politics today. We will look at such historical and contemporary controversies as the Iraq War, the Arab Spring, the rise of ISIS, and the Jamal Khashoggi affair. In each given case, we will trace various ways in which the questions we addressed in the first half of the course continue to inhabit the narratives about how a supposedly “authentic” Islam figures in Muslims’ search for political and cultural legitimacy in modern times. Thus, the course does not aim so much to provide a survey of Muslims politics, but to develop a critical perspective on the key concepts and images that frame Muslims’ and non-Muslims’ discussions about the convergence between Islam and modern politics.

title: Religious Fundamentalism and Asian Cultures
description: This course aims to introduce the effects of religious fundamentalism on the politics of representation among various Asian cultures. Constituted by peoples of a great variety of ethnicities and languages, national and cultural identities have remained problematic in most countries in Asia. This course will guide students to think through how religious fundamentalism contributes to the making of community identities and its (sometimes militant) politics of difference in Asia. Topics of discussion will include issues of national and ethnic myths, language and religious identities, and the cultural representation of Islamic, Hindu and Christian fundamentalism, etc. in Asia.

title: Religion, Health and Healing
description: Religious traditions contain particular understandings of body and mind, health and wholeness, illness and suffering, healing and transformation. This course will cover the latest discussion on the relationship among religion, health and healing. Also, it will explore the health/healing beliefs and practices in different religious traditions such as Taoism, Judaism, Christianity, Muslim, and New Age Movement, as well as will contrast those beliefs and practices with the hegemony of secular western biomedicine. The central goal of the course will bring students to understand how religious health/healing practices are constructed and experienced as meaningful in today's rapidly changing and globalized world.
